variant.question: Select the correct consequence of a right engine failure with flaps extended, when flying a multi engine aircraft:

options.text: Right roll, flaps will increase the roll.
Left roll, flaps will increase the roll.
Left roll, flaps will decrease the roll.
Right roll, flaps will decrease the roll.

variant.question: A multi-engined aeroplane suffers an engine failure on the right engine while flaps are selected down. How will the aircraft roll, and how do the flaps affect the roll?

options.text: Right roll, and flaps increase the roll.
Left roll, and flaps decrease the roll.
Left roll, and flaps increase the roll.
Right roll, and flaps decrease the roll.

variant.question: You are on an approach with flaps in landing position and ATC instruct you to go-around.  You then immediately suffer an engine failure on the left wing. How will the aircraft behave when established in a nose up attitude?

options.text: Bank towards the left, flaps increase the roll
Bank towards the right, flaps reduce the roll
Bank towards the left, flaps reduce the roll
Bank towards the right, flaps increase the roll

variant.question: Flying a twin-engine aircraft with one engine inoperative, the:

options.text: Controllability is decreased at the low airspeeds associated with low mass.
Controllability is decreased at the high airspeeds associated with high mass.
Controllability can be improved by increasing thrust.
Controllability difficulties will be less with the CG aft.

variant.question: An aircraft suffers an engine failure on a light twin aircraft after take-off. Which of the following actions are appropriate?

options.text: Bank 3 to 5 degrees, and rudder towards the live engine.
Bank 7 to 10 degrees, and rudder towards the dead engine.
Bank 7 to 10 degrees, and rudder towards the live engine.
Bank 3 to 5 degrees, and rudder towards the dead engine.
